mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Changes in Ocean Redox over Earth's History
mods:titleInfo.mods:subTitle: Developing and Utilizing Paleoredox Proxies and Constraining Oxygen Budgets

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.mods:abstract: The Phanerozoic is typically known as an interval in which complex life has developed and thrived. However, there are multiple instances throughout this era in which climatic shifts and extinctions have made it difficult for the development of life. One of the most notable factors affecting marine biota throughout the Phanerozoic is the presence (or lack thereof) of oxygen; thus, better constraining the redox conditions of the ocean is vital during intervals of rapid change. One means to do this is through the development and improvement of novel and useful redox proxies, such as thallium (Tl) isotopes. Using marine sediments off the coasts of California, Mexico, and Peru, various low oxygen conditions were analyzed for Tl isotopes to expand settings known to record seawater values. This work expanded previous studies that failed to look into more suboxic settings and showed that the most accurate seawater records can be found in anoxic environments with elevated sulfide content in pore waters, with other less reducing conditions showing a range of values between seawater and sources. Applying this proxy to the end-Permian mass event (EPME), there are notable shifts in Tl isotopes. Not only was there a visible change towards more anoxic conditions earlier than other proxies can determine, but there was also a sudden rapid negative excursion that indicated short-term oxygenation at the onset of the extinction interval, contributing to the massive loss of life through rapid redox fluctuations. Continuing this work to the next minor extinction event chronologically, the Smithian-Spathian extinction provides a persistence of the low-oxygen conditions that was present at the very beginning of the Triassic following the EPME as well as transient redox fluctuations at the extinction interval. Lastly, to better constrain these anoxic events, a model of oxygen across Oceanic Anoxic Event 2 and the Toarcian Oceanic Anoxic Event was applied. Using these well-studied events, a model comparing excessive oxygen production from burial of organic carbon and pyrite sulfur to large igneous province erupted reductants was created, the results of which showed a large influx of reductants is capable of balancing much of the excess oxygen that should be produced during anoxic events. All of these projects show the importance of redox to understanding the development of Earth's systems, which in turn affected the development of life on the planet throughout the Phanerozoic.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
end-Permian mass extinction, large igneous provinces, oceanic anoxic events, Smithian-Spathian boundary, thallium isotopes, trace metal concentrations

Jeremy D. Owens, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jeannette L. Wulff, University Representative; Seth A. Young, Committee Member; Angela N. Knapp, Committee Member; Vincent Salters, Committee Member.
